script.message: Hi there!
Let's query for local neurons in the left antennal lobe that express glutamate neurotransmitter!

script.query: show glutamatergic local neurons in the left antennal lobe

script.message: 'Show' always clears the visualization panel before visualizing the neurons in the query!
Let's try using 'Show' again.

script.query: Show local neurons in the Ellipsoid Body

script.message: Done. Compare this to the 'Add' demo!
Try it yourself!

show_1.description: Clear the work space and visualize neurons according to a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for local neurons in the left antennal lobe that express glutamate neurotransmitter!

script.query: show glutamatergic local neurons in the left antennal lobe

script.message: 'Add' visualizes the neurons in the query on top of what's in the visualization panel!
Let's try using adding some neurons.

script.query: Add local neurons in the Ellipsoid Body

script.message: Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

add_1.description: In addition to what is currently displayed, visualize the neurons according to a specific query

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for neurons in the ellipsoid body!

script.query: Show local neurons in eb

script.query: Add neurons in og

script.message: Now let's undo what we just did.

script.query: Undo

script.message: Now let's add neurons from the PB.

script.query: Add local neurons in PB

script.message: Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

undo_1.description: Go back to a previous step (UNDO).

script.message: Hi!

script.message: Done

keep_1.description: Filter neurons in the current visualization panel based on a specific query.

Let's query for dopaminergic local neurons in the right medulla.

hide_1.description: Hide or reveal neurons in the current visualization panel based on a specific query.

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for local neurons from the right antennal lobe!

script.message: Now let's color them red.

script.query: Color red

script.message: If only a color is specified, the last queried neurons will be colored.
Neurons to be colored can also be specified. For example, we can color GABAergic neurons blue, using the hex code for blue.

script.query: Color gabaergic neurons 0000FF

script.message: Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!

color_1.description: Color neurons in the current visualization panelvisualization panel based on a specific query

script.message: Hi!
Let's query for local neurons from the right antennal lobe!

script.query: Show local neurons in right al

script.message: Now we clear the visualization panel.

script.query: Clear

script.message: Done
It is all yours now! Try it yourself!
The Neuropil menu accessible from the Header Bar lists all neuropils.
This menu can be used to control the neuropils displayed in the visualization panel.
First we hide all neuropils
Next we toggle a few neuropils
Finally we show all neuropils
Done! Try it yourself!
The Neurons/Synapses menu accessible from the Header Bar lists all neurons and synapses visualized in the visualization panel.
It is useful to highlight, hide, pin neurons of interest when the view in the visualization panel becomes cluttered.
First we visualize some neurons.

script.query: show neurons connecting right optu to left optu

script.message: Now we open the Neurons/Synapses Menu and click on one of the neurons
This has the same effect of clicking on the neuron in the 3D visualization.
and brings up the info panel for this neuron.
We can hide the neuron
reveal the neuron
pin the neuron
unpin the neuron
and delete the neuron
Done! Try it yourself!

neuron_menu.description: Access the list of neurons and synapses in the visualization panel to highlight, retrieve info of, pin, hide and delete individual neurons.

script.message: You can use your mouse to navigate through neurons in the visualization panel.
Let's first bring up neurons in the Ellipsoid Body!

script.query: Show local neurons in the Ellipsoid Body

script.message: To highlight a neuron, move mouse cursor onto the displayed neuron.
Let's try another neuron.
To obtain the detailed info about this neuron, single click on the neuron.
Info Panel on the left will display basic info of the neuron, and the synaptic partners of the neuron. Check out the 'Info Panel' demo for more information on how to use the Info Panel
Double-clicking a neuron pins the neuron.
Double-clicking it again to unpin.
Done! Try it yourself!

pin_select_highlight.description: Mouse operations in the visualization panel to highlight, retrieve info of, pin and delete individual neurons.

script.message: Here we show the function of the buttons on the top right.
Clicking on the button, the GUI Usage Info will pop out.
Now let's make a simple query

script.query: show neurons connecting right antennal lobe to right lateral horn
add local neurons in right lateral horn

script.message: We can use the button zoom into the neurons visualized.
Let's take a screenshot of the visualization using the button .
We can reset the view to the original by clicking on button.
Now we will pin some of the neurons

script.query: pin local neurons in right lateral horn

script.message: We can hide everything but the pinned neurons using the button
and reveal everything in the visualization panel using the button
We can remove all neurons except the pinned neurons by the button
To remove pinned neurons but keep unpinned neurons, you will need to use the Neurons/Synapses Menu.
Done! Try it yourself!

gui_buttons.description: Function of the GUI button on the top right.

script.message: Let's explore some inferred connectivity (using the SPIN algorithm ) in the central complex
Let's add some neurons from the central complex to the scene
We first add some tentative EB ring neurons

script.query: show neurons connecting lat to eb
color red

script.message: We then add some tentative EPG, PEG and PEN neurons

script.query: add neurons with inputs in the ellipsoid body and outputs in both pb and idfp
color blue
add neurons with inputs in pb and outputs in both eb and idfp
color lime
add neurons with inputs in pb and outputs in eb and noduli
color yellow

script.message: Now let's open Graph View to see the neuronal graph with the button.
Now let's download the inferred connectivity between these neurons by using the button
Done! Try it yourself!

connectivity_1.description: Explore the connectivity of visualized neurons with buttons

script.message: The settings menu can be accessed by clicking on icon on the top right
Browse through the setting to see what settings can be customized.
Done! Try it yourself!

visualization_settings.description: Open Visualization Settings to change background color, neuropil color, how neurons are rendered, etc.

script.message: A reference of supported English queries can be found by clicking on the button left to the search bar.

Info Panel provides all information available of a neuron.

script.query: show local neurons in EB

script.message: Simply click on the neuron in the visualization panel or from the Neurons/Synapses menu to bring up its information.
You can bring up one of pre- and post-synaptic partner by clicking on the + button in the list of partners.
You can bring up all of its pre- and post-synaptic partner according to the filtered value.
Done! Try it yourself!

infopanel.description: Bring up Info Panel for the neuron to access detail information abou the neuron and its synaptic partners.

dendrite_axon_2.description: Visualize neurons connecting antennal lobe to both left and right lateral horn.

script.message: Hi!
It is known that Lobula Plate Tangential Cells are an essential component of optomotor responses.
Let's try and find some  LPTCs from the FlyCircuit data:

script.query: show neurons connecting the left lop to the left cvlp

script.message: Now let's add neurons from the other side of the brain.

script.query: add neurons connecting the right lop to the right cvlp

script.message: Now let's select from the visualization panel some tangential cells and pin them.
Let's remove the unpinned neurons.
And unpin all the pinned neurons.
Now let's hide the neurons one by one
Let's bring back one of the neurons!
Done
Try exploring detailed information from the Info Panel!

lptc.description: Query for Lobula Plate Tangential Cells.

script.message: The Lobula Plate Tangential Cells (LPTCs) are essential elements in the fly optomotor pathway. Two types of LPTCs have been the subject of intensive investigation. However, more than 20 anatomical classes of LPTCs are known in the blowfly (Hausen, 1984, Fig. 3). Little is known about the existence and if exist, the function the their homologies in the fruit fly visual system. Here we use NeuroNLP to identify LPTCs that may exist in the FlyCircuit data, and their anatomical classes.

Most of the literature shows that LPTCs have extensive dendritic arborizations in the lobula plate (LOP) and can terminate either in the contralateral LOP, or in the ipsilateral and/or contralateral caudal ventrolateral protocerebrum (CVLP)
We first search for the former.

script.query: show neurons connecting left lop to right lop
add neurons connecting right lop to left lop

script.message: We found two types of neurons based on their morphology
The first type resembles the H1 neurons
The other two neurons are possibly of an unknown type or V3.
We now search for LPTCs that connect to ipsilateral CVLP.

script.query: show neurons connecting left lop to left cvlp
add neurons connecting right lop to right cvlp

script.message: Let's remove the unpinned neurons.
And unpin all the pinned neurons.
Among these we have CH cells, whose cell bodies are characteristically located around the oesophagus.
Next we highlight a VS cell.
Then we have an unknown type but its arborization in Lobula plate resembles V1 cells.
and a type of LPTC that has vertical arborization pattern.
Next, we search for LPTCs that sends to the contralateral CVLP.

script.query: show neurons connecting left lop to right cvlp
add neurons connecting right lop to left cvlp

script.message: We found one neuron resembling H2 neuron.
and some resembling H3 neuron.
and some resembling H4 neuron.
Done! Explore it yourself!

fig2b.description: Defining subclasses of the Lobula Plate Tangential Cells.
fig2b.category: Exploring the structure of 2 figures in 'The Fruit Fly Brain Observatory: From Structure to Function'. DOI: 10.1101/580290

script.message: In Fischbach and Dittrich (1989), only one type of Lobula Plate (LOP) local neuron was observed. Mauss et al. (2015) identified two types of glutamatergic inhibitory local neurons that bi-stratify in layers 3/4 of Lobula Plate (LPi neurons), including the one mentioned in Fischbach and Dittrich (1989). With NeuroNLP, we ask if we can further expand the local neuron cell types in the LOP.
We first query glutamatergic neurons in the LOP and select neurons that resemble the tiling pattern of LPi 3-4 neurons.

script.query: show glutamatergic local neurons in lop

script.message: Here, we observe that there are some neurons that have smaller arborization fields that matches the description of LPi 3-4 in Mauss et al. (2015). We pick out these neurons in the left LOP and look at their tiling pattern.

We also observe that there are neurons that have elongated arborization field that stretch through the lobula plate in dorsal-ventral axis. We pin a few of them in the right LOP so that they tile the LOP.
Are there any other local neurons in the LOP?

script.query: show GABAergic local neurons in lop

script.message: It looks like there are a few GABAergic local neurons, with similar shapes as glutamatergic local neurons.

script.query: show cholinergic local neurons in lop

script.message: There are also more cholinergic local neurons of similar shapes as glutamatergic local neurons. However, from the sample of neurons in the database, glutamatergic neurons are majority of local neurons in the LOP.
Done! Explore it yourself!

fig2c.description: Discovering a new type of LPi local neuron in the Lobula Plate.
fig2c.category: Exploring the structure of 2 figures in 'The Fruit Fly Brain Observatory: From Structure to Function'. DOI: 10.1101/580290

script.message: In Sun et al. (2017), a two-stage visual pathway  between the medulla and the bulb (BU, or lateral triangle) was uncovered. This identifies potential sources of visual input to ring neurons that links BU and EB, a neuropil that is believed to maintain an internal compass of the fly. We can inspect this pathway by a few queries and GUI operations

script.query: show neurons that connect right OPTU to right LAT

script.message: This query results in 1 neuron referred to as TB neuron in Sun et al. (2017)

script.query: add neurons that connect left optu and left lat

script.message: We found 4 GABAergic TB neurons
and 1 cholinergic TB neuron

Note that previous experiments have only shown that TB neurons are excitatory, as ex vivo optogenetic activation of a TB neuron led to increased calcium activity in ring neurons (Sun et al., 2017). The results of these two queries suggest that additional experiments are necessary to dissect the input signals to ring neurons.
Now  we  can  inspect  the  inferred  postsynaptic neurons of these TB neuron.
We add one neuron that resemble the Ring neuron
We add two more Ring neurons
This suggests that indeed the TB neuron putatively provide inputs to ring neurons.
We now inspect the TB neuronâ€™s inferred presynaptic partners.
We add one neuron that projects from Medulla
We add another neuron that projects from Medulla

script.query: add neurons that connect left medulla to left optu
add neurons that connect right MED to right OPTU

script.message: We found two distinct populations of neurons projecting from Medulla to OPTU. The first population project to the ventral proximal parts of the OPTU, overlapping with the area where TB neurons extend their dendrites. These neurons seem to match the description of the MT neurons (Sun et al, 2017). They have large dendritic arborization in the middle layers of medulla - potentially in layer 6 where they receive color visual information. A majority of them are cholinergic, but a few others are GABAergic.

A second population project their axons to more dorsal part of the OPTU. Their dendrite innervate only the proximal medulla and are restricted in the parts of medulla that receive visual infornation from the lower back sides of the eyes.
We remove the second population of neurons that innervate the upper part of OPTU. Many of them are fru expressing neurons.

script.query: remove fru expressing neurons

script.message: We add a few putative presynaptic neurons that receive contralateral inputs.
For another neuron.
And yet another.
Done! Explore it yourself!

fig3b.keyword: Fig 3b. A Visual Pathway to EB
fig3b.description: Constructing a visual pathway to EB from connectome data based on Sun et al. (2017).
fig3b.category: Exploring the structure of 2 figures in 'The Fruit Fly Brain Observatory: From Structure to Function'. DOI: 10.1101/580290
